positive.review:
Immortal Redneck, only with friends.

I'll note that the game is addictive; we played for 10 hours in one night session.

+Co-op.
The synchronization between players is very good. There are no unexpected disconnects.
Each player has their own drops, their own guns, their own scrolls, but they can be exchanged with each other.

Typically, similar games, like Deep Rock, have a chill zone where players can rest between runs and play minigames. This is missing here, and it's missing.

+Bosses.
At the time of writing this review (6nov), there are 3 bosses available, each with their own mechanics.

+Pleasant visual style.
The graphics are easy on the eyes, yet all enemy skills are visible.

+Variety.
For an early access game, the variety of guns and passive skills is decent. You can partially choose which direction to take (survivability, damage, mobility, etc.).
You can experiment with builds, making them different every run.

Weapons, like scrolls, aren't all unlocked right away. They unlock as you achieve certain in-game achievements.
But for the most part, it's the player's skill itself that matters, rather than leveling up.
Leveling up simply simplifies the gameplay.
After 10 hours, we progressed further not because we were super-leveled, but because we had gained certain knowledge about enemies, learned the map, and adapted to the shooting mechanics.

P.S. The game is very similar to Immortal Redneck, from the graphics to the gameplay.
P.S.S. Objectively, judging by the reviews, people really liked Gunfire Reborn, and the most important thing now is that the developers don't stop adding new content.

Unpleasant moments

-Hitboxes.
They're good in open spaces, but when there's an obstacle, bullets fly into an invisible texture.

You also can't shoot between planks, where a huge gap is clearly visible, but the bullets just shatter into thin air.

-Variety.
Regarding the "random events" that make gameplay more difficult in some rooms, which is good because it gives players a challenge.
There are three such events, and they repeat over and over again.

It would be EXTREMELY interesting to solve some puzzles.
They would fit the theme of this game, and again, it would add variety.
There needs to be an incentive to explore the area. To do this, we need to create secrets (breakable walls, a specific soundtrack in some corner of the location,

-Master.
The NPC who upgrades weapons has a very sad look. Too bad ))))

What I'd like to see in the future.

1-Marks.
The ability to mark enemies and portals that other people in the lobby can see is really needed in this game.

2-Normal challenges.
Which can be selected at the START of the campaign, and which will provide a small reward.
You need something like "Kill 50 enemies with headshots," "Evade 15 enemy abilities," "Deal 1,000,000 damage."

3-Weekly challenges.
With some kind of enhanced enemies, like "Defeat 3 bosses in a row" or "Survive 15 waves," which would award, for example, 500 upgrade points, and they would only be available once a week.

4. Skins.
It's a small thing, but it's nice to be able to customize your cat (the main character) and weapons.

5. Puzzles and secrets on the map.

6. Statistics.
Statistics on how long it took to kill the boss, and which player in the party dealt the most damage to it.

7. Path Choice.
So that players can choose between the easy path or the hard one, where, for example, the enemies are elite, but completing it will yield a more valuable reward.

The game itself is excellent ‚Äî pure fun and mechanical expressiveness.
However, the lack of a clear roadmap makes it hard to decide whether it‚Äôs worth buying or not. Everything that comes out lately is just DLCs selling characters.

Right now, the game only has 4 stages, 6 unlockable characters (4 through leveling and 2 through mastery points, with one of them being absurdly useless), and 8 paid characters ‚Äî all of which are incredibly strong.
A huge number of weapons are also locked behind DLCs.

It‚Äôs sad to see such a promising game taking the simplest route to make quick money.

That said, I had a great time playing it. Still, running through the same 4 stages over and over gets repetitive. The Mastery System genuinely adds something valuable to the experience, and the extra game modes are really good.

Consider buying it only if you‚Äôre aware that you‚Äôll likely spend another $5/‚Ç¨5 per DLC (there are 4‚Äì5 so far) just to play new characters and weapons ‚Äî all within the same 4 stages. 

(Small Plus: The final bosses of each stage do change after u beat them. So that helps it; I would probably aim to a 36/48 runs before its too repetitive and dull in the normal version of the game.)

I immediately became obsessed with this game. The artsyle and gameplay loop checks so many boxes for me, personally.
The weapons are all very fun or satisfying to use, and the characters all feel pretty different and powerful in their own ways. 
Not one run has felt the same as another. This game very much scratches an itch I didn‚Äôt know I had. Super fun, super replayable. Very much recommend.

6/10

Game loop is fun, good amount of depth. Fun to play with friends. The meta, everything surrounding the game loop, is where it struggles.

It's a coop game without drop-in. You start in a lobby and play to the end. This means your time budget needs to be flexible and you better have a stable internet connection. No computer restarts, no urgent family business, no "only play for an hour" buddy sessions. You cannot join games that have been started.

For comparison, Shape of Dreams saves the current run per completed stage and allows you to resume it together. Nothing of that sort in Gunfire Reborn.

Another issue is that it is unoptimized, prone to stutter, which is noticeable in an fps game. Some maps, some positions, some angles, can cause massive frame drops, often not bad enough to make the game unplayable because you keep moving, but it is not a smooth experience and feels frustrating when you're used to stable framerates. Don't expect an actual fps. It's an fps style roguelite.

The game is very Chinese. English localization is functional but at times hard to understand. Some tooltips are still straight-up in Chinese. On the plus side, there seems to be a decent wiki that explains the gibberish.

Still having fun with friends, but even though we are the ideal test group with no time constraints and no issue playing the same game for hours, patiently waiting for each other if family business calls, I still feel the strain from not being able to save at some point or drop out for half an hour and rejoin,
Or the classic: starting a solo game and then someone comes online and you restart to play with them, and then the next guy comes online and you two restart to play as three.

The game is super arcade-y, so there really is no design reason for it either, other than "hasn't been done yet". Doesn't feel like an adventure, final boss doesn't feel like an achievement. It's just spending 1-2 hours getting overpowered and talking about how overpowered everything is. The limitation of no drop-in is odd. It even technically looks weird, since Steam still allows you to invite friends to a running game, and they won't even see you're already in a game, they'll see you idle in lobby. So you better have voice comms or you're sitting there waiting for the host to ready up.

Fun is had, however. Just feels tedious. Maybe that'll get implemented at some point.

It‚Äôs like Borderlands met Kung Fu Panda in a roguelite fever dream. You‚Äôre a cute animal with way too many guns, yelling ‚ÄúI got this!‚Äù right before a beetle deletes you. 10/10 ‚Äî adorable chaos.
The characters in this game are very fluffy and cute, the game is fun too

Gunfire Reborn is a roguelike shooter with stylized cell-shaded graphics. The game has a steep difficulty curve and limitless variations of each weapon. Progression comes at a steady pace and the multiplayer offers a great cooperative adventure. Several of the characters and weapons are locked behind paid DLC, but the base game has plenty of content to warrant purchasing, especially if it's on sale.

Pretty good coop roguelite, a bit slow as a shooter (Roboquest has much faster pace) and locations variations aren't too exciting, but game is decent and great in all other aspects (performance and bugs wise too), so it's definitely pass and pleasant in all way around game with much space for build experimentation.

This game is a cocktail of everything we love: intense gunfights, tons of different loot, a character development system that makes you come back, and, of course, a co-op mode that will either strengthen your friendships or completely destroy them.

üß†Gunfire Reborn is the perfect choice for those who are tired of giant games and just want to play something that brings pure, unabashed pleasure. It is easily addictive, offers plenty of opportunities for experimentation and fun. It is one of those games that you return to again and again. It does not try to be something that it is not, and this makes it even more attractive.

The gameplay is quite simple - we choose a hero and run through the level, along the way killing enemies that get in our way. The levels are quite small and linear, although sometimes there are secret locations, for passing which you can get a reward. We go through several levels, and at the end a boss awaits us. We repeat this process three times (or four times at higher difficulty levels) - and now, the race is over.

Each of the available heroes has its own skill tree, its own unique skill and its own specific "grenades" - for example, a dog throws just a regular grenade, while for a leopard this grenade takes the form of chain lightning. The skill tree, in turn, is divided into three different branches, which mainly focus on strengthening the main skill, "grenades" or damage/effects from weapons. Thus, each of the characters can be developed in at least three different ways, which, in turn, also adds variability to the gameplay.

‚úÖPros.
- Fast-Paced Combat
- Co-Op Multiplayer
- Progression & Upgrades
- Character Variety

‚ùåCons.
- Repetitive Gameplay
- Lack of Narrative Depth
- Limited Solo Progression
- Randomness Can Be Frustrating

üßæSummary.
Despite all the variety in terms of weapons/character development, in terms of environment the game does not grab stars from the sky. Each stage consists of several possible templates that are superimposed on the level. Therefore, in just a few races, you will see most of the possible environment options, after which there will be only repetition. If this element is critical for you, then the game will most likely bore you quickly.

Gunfire Reborn is a blast for fans of roguelikes and cooperative FPS action. If you enjoy experimenting with different builds, the challenge of progressing further on each run, and team-based play, it‚Äôs a rewarding experience. But if you're not fond of repetitive gameplay or solo challenges, you may find it lacking.
7/10üîö

üéÆFrom the very beginning, the game doesn't leave you in suspense about the pace. The tutorial is a pleasure to complete, immediately showing you and allowing you to experience the incredibly enjoyable dynamics of the game. After a brief introduction, you can begin your first attempt at defeating swarms of diverse enemies and disproportionately gigantic bosses. Such a concise introduction is very satisfying, especially when you think of the multitude of unnecessary tutorials that we have to laboriously wade through in many other games.

Fortunately, the game doesn't slow down at all afterward. The shooting mechanics are incredibly satisfying, but it's important to remember that many enemies' shields are bullet sponges, and they don't react to significant damage. Well, there's no point arguing with genre standards, especially if the developers manage to inject a ton of joy into the game, although it's worth cautioning those who shy away from this approach to eliminating enemies.

The arsenal our heroes can wield is remarkably diverse and offers a completely different approach to exterminating unwilling opponents. Weapons include energy rifles, acid-firing pistols, bows with exploding arrows, and crossbows that shock enemies with electricity. Furthermore, some weapons have a secondary (more powerful) firing mode. While the variety of weapons available for inflicting harm cannot be denied, it's worth noting that many weapons appear in almost every game. I didn't find this to be a significant obstacle, but it can become somewhat tedious in the long run. It's worth noting, however, that the balance of acquired weapons isn't ideal; sometimes you might encounter a weapon that weakens you significantly or increases your power dramatically.

Gear alone, however, isn't everything. You also collect scrolls throughout the game, which have specific effects on damage dealt, health points, critical hit chance, and the effects of hero skills. These are divided into primary skills (like a ball that freezes enemies or a claw attack) and secondary skills (various grenade variations or special attacks with different effects). Both are assigned separately to our anthropomorphic heroes, of which there are currently six. They differ not only in their skills but also in their personal attributes, such as health, shield, and movement speed. Each character plays differently, and it's a lot of fun to discover a new style of play; especially since all skills, when used correctly (and upgraded with scrolls), can completely change the course of the game.

The levels are one of the game's main attractions. Boss fights divide the stages into individual sections, each set in a different location, which adds a fresh feel after the previous levels. The polygon-based graphic style is certainly commendable, as I think it's simply very pleasing to the eye and lends a lighthearted feel to the entire game.

Each level is filled with exploding barrels with various effects that must be utilized appropriately; Otherwise, we run the risk of enemies taking advantage of us. Individual stages don't last particularly long. To reach the final boss, we must overcome 10 procedurally generated levels with regular enemies (with optional passages to vaults, where we participate in a specific challenge as a reward) and several boss fights.

After completing the entire stage for the first time, we gain access to the Elite difficulty setting, which, of course, offers more challenging challenges, but the more lucrative rewards effectively encourage us to play this mode. Furthermore, after defeating the final boss, we gain access to a short but quite challenging bonus map. We also gain access to daily challenges from the main menu. These things ensure that the endgame isn't the slightest bit tedious, especially considering the two higher difficulty levels.

As long as we play dynamically and thoughtfully enough, the game shouldn't pose any major challenges. However, this begins when we're momentarily blinded by inattention, as the game quickly reminds us what we should be focusing on. You can die very quickly, even if you just had full armor and a brimming health bar. Enemies can set you on fire, shock you, or poison you (and we can kill them too), effectively draining your life. However, the game is prepared for this possibility. It allows you to revive once in exchange for a currency called "soul essence," which you accumulate over many playthroughs. The cost of reviving isn't particularly high; you often earn enough in a single playthrough, but it can sometimes sway your decision to abandon further action.

In addition to the single-player mode, the game also offers a cooperative online mode, which, in principle, doesn't deviate from the standard gameplay, and I'd even venture to say it greatly enhances the experience of dispatching hordes of enemies. Matchmaking with strangers works very smoothly, although you can, of course, invite your friends if they also own the game. Playing with multiple players becomes even more dynamic during battles; other players are often helpful, swapping weapons, pointing out interesting scrolls, and greatly assisting in combat by using various skills. It's hard to get bored while playing together, and I highly recommend trying the multiplayer mode for those who usually shy away from the online aspects of various games.

However, if someone doesn't shine on the battlefield from the start, there's nothing to worry about. If you consistently play and hone your skills, you'll gain a significant amount of the aforementioned "soul essence," which you can use to purchase permanent upgrades called talents. The skill tree is so extensive that purchasing all the upgrades should take several dozen hours of gameplay.

üëçPros.
- Fun surface-level combat
- Vault stages
- Consequential bosses.

üëéCons.
- Samey runs
- Quickness of death
- Movement isn‚Äôt encouraged
- Disconnect between single- and multiplayer designs

üèÅSummary.
You'll have to experience it for yourself. Fans of the roguelite genre will undoubtedly love this title and will spend dozens, if not hundreds, of hours playing it. If I had to name games it's similar to, I'd naturally mention Enter the Gungeon, which has a very similar gameplay structure; Shadow Warrior, with its similar approach to shooting and using elements against specific enemies; and the Borderlands series, as Gunfire Reborn has looter shooter elements. If any of these games resonate with you, it's definitely worth considering playing this title.

Tldr: Buy it. If you like shooting things, you will have a ton of fun. 
·ûµ
It‚Äôs an amazing game. No mindless farming for progression, no masochistic grinding for success, just pure fun. It also contains one of my all-time favorite weapons in shooters: No, none of the wacky ones, but the basic-ass rifle named Revealer. Even without special effects, it is just so damn satisfying to spread the love (in the form of headshots), that I can't stop myself from picking it up every time I see it. 
·ûµ
The core game loop is simple yet effective: You start with a basic pistol with infinite ammo, and get to choose a first main weapon from a random selection of three as well. After that, you‚Äôll be constantly presented with new weapons, skills, character upgrades, ways to enhance the weapon you already have, etc. Everything happens one thing at a time, so there is never a moment where you are confused or overwhelmed; The only hesitation will come from the strategies and builds forming in your head, which is what roguelikes/-lites are supposed to do.

All of them are also significant in their nature, so you‚Äôll never have to gripe with getting some bs like ‚Äú+2% weapon damage‚Äù that feel (and are) worthless: Double the headshot damage, but halve the damage if you miss? There we go baby!
·ûµ
Same goes for the meta progression, they are neither the useless ‚Äúplay for 1 hour to get <+1% weapon damage>‚Äù, nor the gatekeeping ‚Äúplay for 1h to get <ability to reload weapons>‚Äù type ‚Äì every upgrade has an impact on gameplay, yet none is necessary to beat it: Perfect.
·ûµ
One thing to mention is the ‚ÄúFPS x Roguelite x RPG‚Äù marketing; I have no idea where the ‚ÄúRPG‚Äù part comes from. Yeah, sure, you‚Äôre playing a role, but you‚Äôre doing that in essentially all games. This contains no story, no dialogue, and only 5 individual upgrades per char, which are completely linear and choiceless. 
·ûµ
Which brings me to my last point: The game is focused on what it does best. There is no tacked-on story, no boiler-plate dialogue with NPCs, no forced quests (albeit there being opportunities to accept challenges for rewards), and no tutorials or explanations outside the main menu - you are truly just running, gunning, and molding your character into a godly angel of death. Absolutely perfect to listen to music, a podcast or an audio-book in the background. 
·ûµ
Regarding the DLCs: Don't believe the nay-sayers that they are in any way, shape, or form predatory: The base game offers around 50h of fun for the average player, and around 100h if it really hits the mark for you. So I would have given it an absolute recommendation for 30$, let alone for 15-20$. Btw.: The 50h are based on an early version of the game with up to season 3 content available, now the game is at 7; All of them are and stay available and introduce new mechanics, so the 50h are probably a low estimate. 
·ûµ
So, do I have something negative to say as well? Kinda: 
[list]
    [*]Weapons have enchantments, up to a bunch of them. But getting a specific weapon to have a set of (more or less) specific enchantments is somewhere between difficult and impossible. This isn‚Äôt really bad, as it is a design and balancing decision, (otherwise everyone would immediately craft the ‚ÄúPrimordial God-Killer 9000‚Äù) ‚Äì still, I‚Äôd wish for more flexibility there. 
    [*]Same goes for leveling the weapons; Weapons drop with levels, which you can increase with money. But if you sank a bunch of coin into a specific one, you will be very hesitant to switch to a new one ‚Äì even if it is the same with better enchantments - as all those levels go down the drain. So some way of transferring or merging levels would be great (and a simple money return doesn‚Äôt cut it either, as the amount of times you can upgrade at a single vendor are limited by default).
    [*]More maps: Look at my playtime. New weapons and characters in the DLCs are cool, but what I need are more enemies and biomes, preferably with some enemy types being a counter to certain strategies, e.g. having specific element immunities, a hidden CRIT-spot, or stuff like that, to spice up the gameplay. And I am more than willing to pay for that!
[/list]

So yeah, in sum: Buy it. If you like shooting things, you will have a ton of fun.

[h2]I love this game so much[/h2]

I wish this game had a demo, I would have bought it sooner, free weekend on top of sale, new contents and dlc launch was big brain move.

This game and Roboquest are extremely similar like they are almost twin, it's hard not to compare them, Roboquest is obviously a superior product but Roboquest is too balanced, the devs are obsessed with balancing like they are Bungie with Destiny 2. I have never had a run where I felt like I have broke the game like in many other roguelikes/lites, I mean it's a roguelite, big numbers should go brrrr right? This is where Gunfire Reborn truly outshine.

Every single run is so consistence, rewards will always increase your dps, improves your build or survivability one way or another, there's no niche items, there's no bad weapons, they're all depends on your character and build. Numbers will start out small but by the end of the run you should be in range of hundred thousands if not millions damage.

Every character have at least 3 builds you can play with, a weapon focus build, a primary/secondary skill build or a mix of both. Yes there are a lot of DLC characters and weapons but the base game have 6 characters and plenty of weapons already. You don't need them unless you want more contents or 100%. Although second character should have unlocked within the first few hours so people don't have to be stuck with the first character for many runs.

Difficulties doesn't hit you like a wall either but a slowly incline hill. There are more contents once you unlocked the highest difficulties. You will need meta progression to actually start winning but I never felt like I have to grind instead of just playing because it's fun and get meta currency.

Co-op is fun, you should play with at least a bot teammate for free revives early on if you don't have friends but do not play with people who have maxed out meta progression, they'll just blast through the game and leaving you behind it's not fun at all as a new player.

Movement kinda suck compare to Roboquest, only dodge, no double jumps, no grappling hook, no character that can fly/float, you just walk all the time, sometime really fast but that's it.

English translation is fine most of the time but the new season 6 content translation is not great sometime, the wordings could be confusing or inconsistent. 

Without a firing range it's very hard to tell whether or not something you just added to your build actually work or not especially later in the run where so many things can happen in a single shot.

I can see why some people like this more than Roboquest. Roboquest is a movement shooter first roguelite after so their build making aspect is honestly weak where Gunfire Reborn is a roguelite first FPS after so it's really depends on your reference.

I'm close to 100% the game and I'm not even close to experience everything this game has to offer. I hope the devs will add a firing range like Roboquest.

Edit: Forgot to mention that there are multiple seasonal mechanics that add tons of depth to the gameplay, you can choose to play with any seasons mechanic at any time or without them. These mechanics are really fun, some can completely change how you play. There are also daily challenge and another game mode which I haven't tried yet.
